properties.name: Norman Hall
properties.description: Built in 1932, this historic building on the University of Florida campus was the original location of the P.K. Yonge Developmental School. During this time, an accident in the building’s elevator killed several children, whose spirits are said to roam the halls even today. Sounds of running and child-like laughter can sometimes be heard on the third floor.

properties.name: Thomas Hall
properties.description: This historic dormitory on the University of Florida campus is haunted by former cafeteria cook Steve. Students claim to hear sounds of pots and pans banging together as Steve walks through the building’s halls.

properties.name: The Hippodrome
properties.description: Before it was converted into a local theater in 1973, the Hippodrome State Theater was a U.S. Post Office and District Courthouse. This Downtown Gainesville landmark is a prime destination for both the living and dead, boasting multiple instances of ghostly tragedy. One such instance involves a woman and her son, murder convict Clement Boyle. Before his scheduled hanging, Clement’s mother attempted to bring in evidence that would have led to his acquittal. However, she arrived too late, and soon after died of grief. Her weeping spirit now wanders the Hippodrome in search of her son. The theater’s dressing area, previously the courthouse basement, is also home to the spirits of many male prisoners.

properties.name: Beaty Towers
properties.description: The Beaty Towers residence halls, located on the University of Florida campus, are available to both current and former students. At one point, a female student committed suicide by jumping out of her dormitory bedroom onto the nearby US-441 highway. Echoed sobbing can be heard coming from the building’s walls as her ghost roams through the buildings.

properties.name: Sweetwater Branch Inn
properties.description: Located in the Historic Bed and Breakfast district in Downtown Gainesville, Sweetwater Branch Inn is rich with paranormal activity. The Inn’s two houses, one pink and the other blue, are both protected by a friendly ghost. In addition, the blue house contain many spirits who often descend from their attic dwelling to disturb the Inn’s guests and housekeepers. Even the Inn’s owners have spotted specters peering out of the upstairs windows of the house.

properties.name: The Antique Emporium
properties.description: Previously known as Wayside Antiques, this antique store located just south of Gainesville has been haunted for about 30 years. In 1986, the store’s owners, Mr. and Mrs. Branum, were robbed and murdered in the building. According to crime scene analysis, one spouse had to witness the other being brutally murdered before their subsequent death. The tragic nature of this crime is likely the reason why employees, locals, and even psychics have all experienced mysterious paranormal activity throughout the store.

properties.name: The Social
properties.description: This spot in Gainesville’s Midtown area is popular among both college students and malicious local ghouls. Before its reconstruction, the building housed The Purple Porpoise. Allegedly, a girl was assaulted and murdered in the building’s restroom in the 1960s. Ever since, a spirit has roamed the upstairs level, attacking female patrons in the building’s narrow hallway and bathroom.

properties.name: Steak 'n Shake
properties.description: This beloved Steak ’n Shake, located just southeast of the University of Florida campus, was once the scene of a gruesome crime leaving the establishment infested with ghosts. During the late 1970s, felon Darren Sheppard held three Steak ’n Shake employees at gunpoint, then forced them into the restaurant’s walk-in freezer. He then shot each in the back of the head, locked them in the freezer, and left them to rot. Two employees died, but the third survived and testified against the perpetrator. Though the building has since been rebuilt, many employees both past and present believe the freezer to be haunted by the two murder victims.

properties.name: Pine Grove Cemetery
properties.description: Located along the Hawthorne Trail, this historic cemetery is a great spot to commune with the dead. We recommend visiting during the Witching Hour.

properties.name: Burlington Coat Factory
properties.description: Until January 2013, this building housed Gainesville’s very own haunted Walmart. The spirit who haunted the store was rumored to have been a former employee. She began inhabiting the store just one month after her death, appearing mostly during the hours of 3AM to 7AM. Her presence was often felt in the Infants, Girls Wear, Jewelry, Crafts, and Domestics departments by both employees and those with heightened psychic abilities. Investigation is still needed regarding whether her spirit remained following the building’s acquisition by the Burlington Coat Factory.

properties.name: Mount Pleasant Cemetery
properties.description: This lovely cemetery, found in Northwest Gainesville, is the perfect spot for orb enthusiasts. Local ghost hunters claim it has the highest success rate for capturing orbs on camera. For best results, go toward the back of the cemetery, which has been left in ruins and contains a concentration of paranormal activity.

properties.name: Yummy House
properties.description: Long ago, this building housed a Goodwill with a secret curse. Shortly after someone died in the store, strange phenomena began to occur. Employees began hearing a female voice calling their names after the store was closed and the doors locked.  Shadows moved along the walls, and mysterious knocking sounds could be heard coming from the rear loading dock in the early morning.

properties.name: Trader Joe's
properties.description: This building was the site of a Goody’s until 2012, when it was taken over by Trader Joe’s. Goody’s employees were often accosted by a ghost that would rearrange inventory, set off alarms, and generally wreak havoc through the store.

properties.name: Devil's Millhopper
properties.description: This well-known geological site, consisting of a large sinkhole fed by twelve natural springs, can be found in Northwest Gainesville. Legend has it that the Devil once fell in love with and kidnapped a Native American woman, with whom he absconded into the woods. As her rescue party followed in pursuit, the Devil created a massive hole into which he could escape, then turned the rescuers into stone. During the full moon, modern-day visitors of the site have occasionally heard moans and screams emanating from the sinkhole.
